Customer Segmentation Using Clustering Techniques


This project focuses on segmenting customers into different groups based on their purchasing behavior and demographics. It uses clustering algorithms like K-means and hierarchical clustering to identify distinct customer segments.

This project involves creating visualizations to show trends in global CO2 emissions over time. It includes data extraction from public databases, data cleaning, and using visualization libraries to create interactive charts and graphs.

title: Chronologies
text:
With over 25 years of experience, Chronologies is a trusted provider of independent, expert advice on scientific dating for archaeological & heritage research. We work closely with academic institutions, heritage professionals, and commercial archaeologists to provide robust, contextually informed chronological frameworks.
Whether you require strategic guidance during project design or expert analysis of complex scientific dating results, we deliver tailored support grounded in current best practice and the latest scientific developments.
At Chronologies, we are committed to enhancing the reliability and interpretive power of archaeological chronologies. Let our expertise guide your next project with confidence and precision.

import seaborn as sns

sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")

# Load the diamonds dataset

# Plot the distribution of clarity ratings, conditional on carat
sns.displot(
    data=diamonds,
    x="carat", hue="cut",
    kind="kde", height=4, aspect=1.5,
    multiple="fill", clip=(0, None),
    palette="ch:rot=-.25,hue=1,light=.75",

title: Publications
text:
One of the most enduring rituals of ‘academic life’ is the dutiful compilation of publications—that familiar litany of books and journal articles for which one must claim responsibility. Presumably this exercise demonstrates scholarly credibility to colleagues, who will scan the accumulated citations and find reassurance in their methodical completeness. While I no longer navigate the corridors of academic institutions, I haven’t entirely abandoned the habit of cataloguing my research output. The record below contains some highlights, for a longer list see Research Gate and Google Scholar.
During my time at English Heritage & Historic England, my research centered on understanding past human behaviors and environmental conditions through scientific analysis—particularly the application of radiocarbon dating and related chronometric techniques to archaeological contexts. The work encompassed radiocarbon calibration, Bayesian statistical modeling of dates, taphonomic processes affecting organic preservation, stable isotope analysis, and the integration of multiple dating methods for robust chronological frameworks. I also explored broader questions of how environmental change influenced cultural transitions and settlement patterns in the archaeological record.
In my current role, my research output has naturally diminished compared to those more productive years. Nevertheless, my ongoing work as a scientific dating consultant continues to generate findings worthy of publication, and these contributions are gradually appearing in the relevant specialist journals .
The map below provides a spatial overview of some of the sites sites & projects I have been fortunate to have worked on.

Basic Navigation: Use the + and - buttons (top left) to zoom in and out of the map Click and drag to pan around different geographic areas
Finding Sites: Blue markers indicate sites or project we have been involved with. Click on any blue marker for links to further inf

title: Peter Marshall
section: Welcome to chronologies
text:
Welcome to chronologies

Specialists in Scientific Dating for Archaeology & the Hertiage Sector
With over 25 years of experience, Chronologies is a trusted provider of independent, expert advice on scientific dating for archaeological & heritage research. We work closely with academic institutions, heritage professionals, and commercial archaeologists to provide robust, contextually informed chronological frameworks.
Whether you require strategic guidance during project design or expert analysis of complex scientific dating results, we deliver tailored support grounded in current best practice and the latest scientific developments.
At Chronologies, we are committed to enhancing the reliability and interpretive power of archaeological chronologies. Let our expertise guide your next project with confidence and precision.

title: About us
text:
Chronologies was founded to meet the growing need for independent, scientifically informed advice on scientific dating. With over 25 years of experience in the field, we bring deep expertise in the application, interpretation, and integration of scientific dating methods across a wide range of archaeological contexts.
Our work has supported major research and heritage-led investigations across the UK and internationally. Notable projects include [Project Name 1], [Project Name 2], and [Project Name 3] — each demonstrating our ability to apply chronological tools to complex archaeological questions. Further details on these and other collaborations can be found on our [Projects] page.
We are also active contributors to the development of dating guidance and best practice. Our co-authored publications include nationally recognised frameworks and methodological reviews, helping to shape the standards by which dating evidence is commissioned, evaluated, and used. Key examples include [Title of Guidance Document] and [Title of Methodological Paper], accessible via our [Resources] section.
Whether advising on sampling strategy, evaluating multi-method chronologies, or supporting publication and otreach, we are committed to delivering clear, context-aware, and scientifically robust input at every stage of the archaeological process.

title: Publications
text:
One of the most enduring rituals of ‘academic life’ is the dutiful compilation of publications—that familiar litany of books and journal articles for which one must claim responsibility. Presumably this exercise demonstrates scholarly credibility to colleagues, who will scan the accumulated citations and find reassurance in their methodical completeness. While I no longer navigate the corridors of academic institutions, I haven’t entirely abandoned the habit of cataloguing my research output. The record below contains some highlights, for a longer list see Research Gate and Google Scholar.
During my time at English Heritage & Historic England, my research centered on understanding past human behaviors and environmental conditions through scientific analysis—particularly the application of radiocarbon dating and related chronometric techniques to archaeological contexts. The work encompassed radiocarbon calibration, Bayesian statistical modeling of dates, taphonomic processes affecting organic preservation, stable isotope analysis, and the integration of multiple dating methods for robust chronological frameworks. I also explored broader questions of how environmental change influenced cultural transitions and settlement patterns in the archaeological record.
In my current role, my research output has naturally diminished compared to those more productive years. Nevertheless, my ongoing work as a scientific dating consultant continues to generate findings worthy of publication, and these contributions are gradually appearing in the relevant specialist journals .

title: Publications
text:
One of the most enduring rituals of ‘academic life’ is the dutiful compilation of publications—that familiar litany of books and journal articles for which one must claim responsibility. Presumably this exercise demonstrates scholarly credibility to colleagues, who will scan the accumulated citations and find reassurance in their methodical completeness. While I no longer navigate the corridors of academic institutions, I haven’t entirely abandoned the habit of cataloguing my research output. The record below contains some highlights, for a longer list see Research Gate and Google Scholar.
During my time at English Heritage & Historic England, my research centered on understanding past human behaviors and environmental conditions through scientific analysis—particularly the application of radiocarbon dating and related chronometric techniques to archaeological contexts. The work encompassed radiocarbon calibration, Bayesian statistical modeling of dates, taphonomic processes affecting organic preservation, stable isotope analysis, and the integration of multiple dating methods for robust chronological frameworks. I also explored broader questions of how environmental change influenced cultural transitions and settlement patterns in the archaeological record.
In my current role, my research output has naturally diminished compared to those more productive years. Nevertheless, my ongoing work as a scientific dating consultant continues to generate findings worthy of publication, and these contributions are gradually appearing in the relevant specialist journals .
